review.title: Summarizing Situational and Topical Information During Crises
review.abstract: The use of microblogging platforms such as Twitter during crises has become widespread. More importantly, information disseminated by affected people contains useful information like reports of missing and found people, requests for urgent needs etc. For rapid crisis response, humanitarian organizations look for situational awareness information to understand and assess the severity of the crisis. In this paper, we present a novel framework (i) to generate abstractive summaries useful for situational awareness, and (ii) to capture sub-topics and present a short informative summary for each of these topics. A summary is generated using a two stage framework that first extracts a set of important tweets from the whole set of information through an Integer-linear programming (ILP) based optimization technique and then follows a word graph and concept event based abstractive summarization technique to produce the final summary. High accuracies obtained for all the tasks show the effectiveness of the proposed framework.

To generate real-time summaries, some approaches to online summarization of tweet streams have been proposed recently [20].The above methods generate extractive summaries that are merely a collection of tweets. Ideally, we prefer an abstract summary of important content from tweets rather than the entire tweets. Such a summary should also be more readable than a collection of tweets.

sections.heading: 3. DATASET AND CLASSIFICATION OF MESSAGES
sections.text: We use the Twitter data of the Nepal Earthquake 2015 from CrisisNLP [10]. The data set consists of 27 million messages from April 25 to 27, which were compiled using various keywords (e.g. Nepal Earthquake, NepalQuake, NepalQuakeRelief, NepalEarthquake, KathmanduQuake, QuakeNepal, EarthquakeNepal, · · ·, etc.). In this work, we selected AIDR [9] classified messages from three categories for which machine confidence was ≥ 0.80. The selected classes and messages in each of the three classes are: 1. sections.heading: 5. IDENTIFICATION OF SUB-TOPICS AND SUMMARIZATION
sections.text: In this section, we cover sub-events / topics that have been classified into a specific category (e.g. infrastructure damage). We define a sub-topic as a combination of a noun and a verb in which noun represents a concept and a verb represents an event (as described in the previous section). In this section, we look for dependency relationships between nounsand verbs that are important to declare some information as an event / topic. Table 3 provides examples of some sub-topic phrases from different AIDR classes. These sub-topics show important but very specific events after the major earthquake crisis.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSION
sections.text: We have presented a new framework to summarize information in crisis-related tweets in two different forms: (a) a general summary of the situation and (b) specific reports on the activity of flashpoints that provide trenchant information about a location and / or event. To paint such a diverse but coherent picture, a deep understanding of the tweets posted during such a scenario is required - we believe that the series of innovations that have been made in this work was the result of a thorough analysis of such tweets. We have also conducted extensive evaluations using experts to determine the benefits of our approach, and in the future we will deploy the system in a way that can be helpful in future disaster events.
